lexUnit.name: beckon.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: make a gesture to encourage or instruct someone to approach or follow

sentence.text: He beckoned Duncan to follow , and the two men left the hotel and got into the Lada parked outside , Duncan putting his bag on the back seat .
I beckoned her to come in and have coffee , but she shook her head and tapped on the glass again and mouthed the words , ` I want you , " like a trapped goldfish .
There Suzan was haunted by visions of her father , beckoning her to come and lie beside his tomb .
He beckoned her to sit between his thighs , and his heart missed a beat when she meekly obeyed .
The nun beckoned him to follow her from the room and , reluctantly , he did so .
He beckons me to follow .
I moved slightly and beckoned the German to come to us .
A heavy door swung open and a figure beckoned them into a warm lozenge of light .
She beckoned Gloria into the dark passage outside the room .
She turned to him , smiling widely now , and beckoned him into the hall .
He beckoned her into the house .
The policemen controlling the pedestrians beckon them across the road .
Slowly , he raised a finger and pointed at a man in the crowd , beckoning him forward in a friendly manner .
The Doctor caught Francis 's eyes , and beckoned him with a nod of the head .
He beckoned Luch forward with his head .
Frau Nordern beckoned Omi .
He beckoned Corbett back to the table .
Bernice beckoned the Doctor over .
Talbot beckoned him out on to the starboard wing .
I glanced quickly towards the island where the siren light still beckoned us on .
Glancing up he saw the senator beckoning for his sons to join him .
Ralph stood up and controlled the flames around and beckoned for the team to run quickly to the staircase .
He peeled one glove off and beckoned like a woman .
The man with the headphones was beckoning urgently .
